thread.title: Royals found their formula to own October
thread.title_full: Royals found their formula to own October

author: azcentral.com
title: Royals found their formula to own October
text:
TORONTO — Kansas City may be one of baseball's smallest markets, but the primary currency amidst the modern media boon is prospects, not dollars, and that's why the rise of the Royals has been foreseen for years.
Back in 2011, Sports Illustrated predicted that the Royals would win the 2015 World Series because of "that amazing Kansas City Royals minor league system."
After routing the Toronto Blue Jays on Tuesday, the Royals are on the precipice of a second straight trip to the Fall Classic, with their 3-1 lead in the American League Championship Series.
Yet, these Royals are not merely negotiating the October gauntlet; they are owning it. The Royals are 17-7 the past two postseasons, with a run differential of +34. Their .708 clip is the best two-year postseason run since the New York Yankees went 18-3 (.857) in the 1998-99 playoffs.
USA TODAY
Unorthodox - but effective - trio carries Royals to cusp of World Series
On their 25-man playoff roster are 11 homegrown players, three stars acquired in trades for K.C. prospects and two other key players less than two years into their big league careers when they settled into Kauffman Stadium. Those 11 homegrown Royals are the most of the remaining four organizations: one more than the Mets, four more than the Blue Jays and six more than the Cubs.
This season's Opening Day payroll of $113 million cracked nine digits for the first time in franchise history and is nearly triple the expenditure of 2011, when that SI proclamation was written. The organization is loosening the purse strings to capitalize on the contender that's been built.
There are a few important players destined for free agency next month — left fielder Alex Gordon, second baseman Ben Zobrist and starter Johnny Cueto — but most of the club remains under team control through 2017.
"Hopefully everybody can stick around as long as they can," said closer Wade Davis, who arrived via trade before the 2013 season and will be around through '17. "It's a great organization, a great place to play, the fans have been fantastic and a beautiful city. It's definitely a great place to be."
The Royals' reliance on scouting and development makes them the envy of much of the majors, even if they're not always lauded by fans as such.
"It's not a big market, so I guess that's why no one really talks about us that much," first baseman Eric Hosmer, a former first-round pick, said. "We've got a good team. We know how good our team is, and a lot of us have been playing together for a long time, which helps a lot. We have a lot of confidence in each other, and that's the biggest thing — to have confidence in the guy next to you and that you believe in each other."
USA TODAY
Blue Jays' special season down to one ALCS game vs. Royals
Since the 1994 strike, Kansas City had just won winning season until 2013 — before that year, Moore pulled the trigger on a blockbuster, shipping out top young hitter Wil Myers and three other prospects for Tampa Bay Rays pitchers Davis and James Shields.
By that point, Royals general manager Dayton Moore had succeeded in building a mostly homegrown core, although his franchise wouldn't have the resources to keep those players around forever.
"You've got a very small window of opportunity to win with a certain group of players," Moore said two years ago, while explaining the trade for Shields. "Our goal all along was for Alex and Billy [Butler] to turn into players and then a young group coming behind them and blending in with their talents.
"... If you wait two, three years and you're still trying to build and what have you, then your window closes rather quickly."
Lasting power is hard in a sport pocked with parity. The last back-to-back AL pennant winners were the Texas Rangers, who did so in 2010 and 2011. They came within an out of a World Series title but fell short — and then didn't return to the Division Series again until this October.
The turnover in those few years is remarkable: only infielders Elvis Andrus and Adrian Beltre remain in the lineup from the 2011 World Series, and only Colby Lewis and Derek Holland remain in the pitching staff. (Mike Napoli and Josh Hamilton were on both clubs but played elsewhere in between.)
"We've looked at that big picture since the start of spring training," injured starter Jason Vargas said. "This is a special group here, a lot of resilience."
Vargas signed a four-year free-agent contract prior to the 2014 season after watching from afar as the budding franchise steadily improved.
"The two or three seasons leading up to free agency, playing against these guys, you see the core unit staying in the same place and learning how to win each year a little bit more and continuing to develop as a group," he said. "That's something I had taken notice of over my time playing against them — seeing how well they meshed together and what a good group of guys they were, mainly because they were all farmed from the same system."
There may well be a mass exodus after 2017 — when Hosmer, Davis, center fielder Lorenzo Cain and third baseman Mike Moustakas all simultaneously become eligible for free agency — but for now and the near-term, the Royals could remain the class of the American League.
